_header: Blowing was made for great game
Note:
For burden appearing separately see 1833, and Windsor, St George’s Chapel, Windsor E.I.I, f. 95v, pr. bad key, 74; Greene (1977)
XGreene, Richard Leighton. The Early English Carols. Oxford: Clarendon, 1935; 2nd ed., rev., Oxford: Clarendon, 1977 (see also Greene (1935)
XGreene, Richard Leighton. The Early English Carols. Oxford: Clarendon, 1935; 2nd ed., rev., Oxford: Clarendon, 1977), 434.
_description: Against Blowing one’s own Horn — six quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘I hold hym wyse and wel itaught / Can bar an horn and blow it nought’

BodEngPoete1.First Lines:
Blowyng was mad for gret gameOf þis blowyng cometh mekell
                    grame…
BodEngPoete1.Last Lines:
…Be war to whom þou tellist þi talebut bar a horne
                    & blow it navgt
